item.title: MAGA Triumphs in Poland’s Presidential Election
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Skolimowski

media:content.media:description: Karol Nawrocki, center, with his wife Marta and their children during an election night rally in Warsaw on June 1. Photographer: Sean Gallup/Getty Images Europe

item.title: Senate Begins Putting Its Stamp on Giant Trump Tax, Debt Limit Bill
item.description: Significant changes are in store for President Donald Trump’s signature $3.9 trillion tax-cut bill as the Senate begins closed-door talks this week on legislation that squeaked through the House by a single vote.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis, Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Senate Republican leadership, from left, John Barrasso, John Thune, and Shelley Moore Capito during a news conference at the US Capitol in Washington.

item.title: Pro-Trump Nationalist Wins Poland’s Presidential Election
item.description: A nationalist candidate backed by Donald Trump secured victory in Poland’s presidential election, defeating the centrist mayor of Warsaw in a contest that could stymie the government’s efforts to shift the nation back into the European Union mainstream.
item.dc:creator: Maciej Martewicz, Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Karol Nawrocki, center, with his wife Marta and their children during an election night rally in Warsaw, Poland, on June 1, 2025.

item.title: Starmer Seeks Nuclear Build-Up in Sweeping UK Military Revamp
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer outlined a sweeping overhaul of the British military, including a costly expansion of the country’s nuclear deterrent, but declined to specify when the UK would meet a key target of spending 3% of national output on defense.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Tom Rees, Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Members of staff during a visit byKeir Starmer to the BAE Systems' Govan facility, in Glasgow, on June 2.

item.title: Trump Plans to Offload National Park Sites, But States Don’t Want Them
item.description: The White House wants to trim the National Park Service budget by transferring some parks to state and tribal management. States say their resources are already tight.
item.dc:creator: Bobby Magill

media:content.media:description: An American alligator defends its mud hole during the dry season in Big Cypress National Preserve.

item.title: Bolsonaro Wants to Stage a Trumpian Comeback. It Might Save Lula’s Presidency
item.description: Jair Bolsonaro’s insistence he can pull off a Donald Trump-like comeback in Brazil’s looming election has paralyzed his fervent right-wing movement, effectively blocking the search for a successor to the ineligible former president.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Carvalho, Raphael Almeida Dos Santos, Beatriz Reis

media:content.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro

item.title: Putin’s Central Banker Under Fire to Cut Record-High Rates
item.description: The Bank of Russia’s governor, who was praised for helping save the country’s economy after the invasion of Ukraine, is facing mounting pressure to reverse course on record-high borrowing costs amid worries over their toll on business.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: Bank of Russia governor Elvira Nabiullina Photographer: Olga Maltseva/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Iran Says US Hasn’t Given Clarity on Sanctions Relief in Nuclear Talks
item.description: Iran warned it won’t strike a nuclear deal with the US unless Washington gives assurances that any agreement will include sanctions removal.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: A man walks past the former US embassy in Tehran, on May 20.

item.title: EU Poised to Curb China’s Access to Medical Device Procurement
item.description: The European Union is set to curb Chinese medical device manufacturers’ access to public procurement contracts in the bloc, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

item.title: Revved-Up Polish Assets Dip With Nationalist Winning Ballot
item.description: Polish stocks and bonds — among the world’s stand-out performers of 2025 — declined after a nationalist unexpectedly won the presidential election, dealing a blow to the government.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko, Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: Poll workers empty the ballot boxes at a primary school before they are counted during the second round of the presidential elections in Gdansk, on June 1, 2025. Photo Mateusz SLODKOWSKI / AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Set to Restart Talks After Kyiv Hits Bombers
item.description: Russia and Ukraine will resume direct peace talks in Istanbul a day after Ukraine staged one of its boldest aerial attacks inside Russia, which destroyed long-range bombers and other aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer, Olesia Safronova

item.title: Europe’s Top Envoy Pitches for Deeper Philippine Defense Ties
item.description: Europe and the Philippines will set up a new “security and defense dialogue,” officials said, in a move that comes as the European Union strengthens ties with Asian nations amid threats from China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon, Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Kaja Kallas and Enrique Manalo in Metro Manila on June 2. Photographer: Jam Sta Rosa/Getty Images

item.title: South Korean Election: Can a New President Bring Back Stability?
item.description: South Koreans are set to finally choose a new president after the nation’s worst constitutional crisis in decades.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Moves to Lift Biden-Era Curbs on Arctic Oil Drilling
item.description: The Trump administration is moving to repeal Biden-era curbs blocking oil drilling across most of the mammoth petroleum reserve in Alaska that’s home to an estimated 8.7 billion barrels of recoverable oil.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: (Photo by Lance King/Getty Images) Photographer: Lance King/Getty Images North America

item.title: At Least 21 Palestinians Killed Heading to Gaza Aid Hub, Hospital Says
item.description: RAFAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — At least 31 people were killed and over 170 were wounded Sunday as large crowds were on their way to receive food in the Gaza Strip, health officials and witnesses said. Witnesses said Israeli forces fired toward the crowds just before dawn around a kilometer (about 1,100 yards) from an aid site run by an Israeli-backed foundation.

media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians ferry bags of food aid after storming a World Food Programme warehouse in Deir el-Balah in the central Gaza Strip on May 28 Photo by Eyad BABA/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: EYAD BABA/AFP

item.title: South Africa’s Black Empowerment Laws and the Long Shadow of Apartheid
item.description: During the eras of colonialism and apartheid, Black South Africans were subjugated, denied a decent education, and excluded from the mainstream economy. Severe racial disparities endure to this day, more than three decades after the end of White-minority rule. South Africa ranks as one of the world’s most unequal countries, according to analysis by the World Inequality Lab.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cohen

media:content.media:description: A waste-picker sweeps the road outside residences in a wealthy suburb of Johannesburg.

item.title: Taiwan Warns of Rise in Chinese Military Activity Around Region
item.description: Taiwan said China escalated military pressure around the region in May, deploying dozens of warships and government vessels daily in what it described as an extreme pressure campaign.
item.dc:creator: Cindy Wang

media:content.media:description: Taiwanese soldiers move in formation during Taiwanese President William Lai's (Lai Ching-te) visit to a military base, in Kaohsiung, Taiwan.

item.title: Philippines Eyes India, Thailand Rice to Cut Vietnam Reliance
item.description: The Philippines, the world’s top rice importer, plans to look beyond its dominant supplier, Vietnam, to ensure steady supplies and competitive prices at home.
item.dc:creator: Neil Jerome Morales, Cliff Harvey Venzon

item.title: China Accuses US of Violating Trade Deal, Vows Firm Response
item.description: China accused the US of violating their recent trade deal and vowed to take measures to defend its interests, dimming the prospect of an immediate leadership call that Donald Trump wants to have to further bilateral talks.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

item.title: Japan’s Akazawa Reportedly Mulls Return to US This Week
item.description: Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa is considering returning to the US for another round of trade negotiations this week as expectations mount for a deal as early as this month.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: Chile Presidential Polls Show Matthei With Slight Lead Over Kast
item.description: Chile center-right presidential candidate Evelyn Matthei held a small lead over more conservative contender Jose Antonio Kast atop two polls published on Sunday, reflecting an open race for the nation’s top job.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Evelyn Matthei Photographer: Cristobal Olivares/Bloomberg

item.title: Southeast Asia Joins Europe’s Calls to Defend Subsea Cables
item.description: Defense officials from Europe and Southeast Asia called for stronger collaboration to protect the global network of subsea cables as concerns grow over threats to this vital infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Underwater Cable On Sea Floor Source: Mint Images/Mint Images/Getty Images

item.title: Hegseth Wins Praise But Asia Still Has Strong Doubts About Trump
item.description: After US military allies in Europe were torched by Vice President JD Vance in March over military spending, free speech and the war in Ukraine, America’s partners in Asia warily awaited Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s arrival at a security conference in Singapore.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Philip Heijmans, Josh Xiao

item.title: UK Non-Dom Exits Seen Hitting at Least 10%, With More to Come
item.description: At least 10% of the UK’s wealthy non-dom population have left the country following tighter tax rules introduced by Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s Labour government, according to a new report authored by a former Treasury economist.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: The Royal Exchange in the City of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 5, 2024. A selloff in the riskier corners of the global market deepened, with stocks plunging and traders rushing to the safety of bonds as concerns about a slowdown in the world’s largest economy intensified. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea’s Election Frontrunner Still Leaves Many Unconvinced
item.description: Lee Jae-myung is still the frontrunner in South Korea’s presidential race, but what once looked like a landslide victory has turned into a much closer contest.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung arrives for a campaign event in Incheon.

item.title: US Calls on Australia to Boost Defense Spending to 3.5% of GDP
item.description: US Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth has asked Australia to dramatically raise its military spending to 3.5% of gross domestic product “as soon as possible,” according to an official readout of his meeting with Australia’s Defence Minister Richard Marles.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: Richard Marles speaks during the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore on May 31.

item.title: South Korea Crypto Industry to Gain No Matter Who Wins Election
item.description: No matter who clinches South Korea’s presidential election this week, one outcome is certain: the country’s crypto industry is poised to win.
item.dc:creator: Sidhartha Shukla

media:content.media:description: Inside of Total crypto mining facility in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, on Thursday, March 28, 2024. Crypto-linked investments have been a popular choice for South Koreans.

item.title: UK to Build More Attack Submarines in ‘Message to Moscow’
item.description: The UK intends to send a “message to Moscow” with plans to expand its fleet of attack submarines and invest in its nuclear deterrent as part of a new defense strategy to head off the threat posed by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: An Astute Class nuclear-powered submarine, at His Majesty’s Naval Base Clyde, Scotland.

item.title: Sudan’s Army-Backed Prime Minister Poised to Form New Government
item.description: Sudan’s army-appointed Prime Minister Kamil Idris dissolved the government in preparation to form a new cabinet, almost two weeks after he was announced as the war-torn country’s first premier in more than three years.
item.dc:creator: Sherif Tarek

media:content.media:description: Members of the Sudanese Armed Forces depart from the Presidential Palace in Khartoum, Sudan, on March 26, 2025.

item.title: Chile’s Boric Vows to Rely Less on Israel, Citing Gaza Violence
item.description: Chile President Gabriel Boric vowed to diversify his nation’s defense ties to depend less on Israel, issuing a scathing rebuke over violence in Gaza during his annual State of the Nation address on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Gabriel Boric speaks during a State of the Nation annual address at the National Congress in Valparaiso, Chile on June 1, 2025. Photographer: Francesco Degasperi/AFP/Getty Images
